subject: Re: [junit] How can I write test case before write concrete cless
msgSnippet: Thanks a lot. I think factories makes better. Because I do not really know how will the constructor be. And these days my friend told me I can give a dummy
messageBody:
Thanks a lot.

I think factories makes better. Because I do not really know how will
the constructor be.

And these days my friend told me I can give a dummy class makes all
methods return null.
First let the unit test case run, and finish my concrete class step by step.

How about this one?

Regards.

Weiming

Kent Beck wrote:
> Weiming,
>
> I can think of several ways you could write your tests. You could
> write the
> test with an example of a concrete class and use constructors:
>
> IMoney addend= new Money(5, "CHF");
>
> You could use factories:
>
> IMoney addend= fiveFrancs();
> or
> IMoney addend= MoneyFactory.fiveFrancs();
>
> The principle I use in such cases is to defer design decisions as long as
> possible. I would start with the variables being declared with a concrete
> class, then introduce interfaces once they would help the code:
>
> Money addend= new Money(5, "CHF");
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of Weiming Yin
> > Sent: Monday, September 05, 2005 12:28 AM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] How can I write test case before write concrete cless
> >
> > I designed some interfaces about my application
> > Now I want to write some unit test case for test these interfaces.
> > But I have no concrete class, how can I write the test case. The
> > constructor is a problem.
> > I can use Factory pattern to solve the problem.
> > Is there any other method to build these cases?
> > I don't want to so much FACTORY.
> >
> > Regards.
> >
> > weiming
>
>
>
